clinical_study.official_title: Improvement of Facial Symmetry With Myofunctional Therapy Combined to Botulinum Toxin Injections in Long Standing Facial Paralysis

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Sao Paulo General Hospital

clinical_study.source: University of Sao Paulo General Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: Objective: Quantify the benefits of myofunctional therapy associated to botulinum toxin injection in patients with long standing facial unilateral palsy.

detailed_description.textblock: Twenty-five patients with long standing facial palsy were studied; all had been previously treated for facial reanimation. Patients were randomly divided in two groups; Group A did the myofunctional therapy sessions with the speech therapist before the botulinum toxin injection, while the participants of Group B did the myofunctional therapy after it.

arm_group.description: All the facial paralysis patients received treatment with botulinum toxin type A to the non-paralyzed side, according to the Institution Protocol. To the participants of Group A, botulinum toxin was applied after myofunctional therapy.

All the facial paralysis patients received treatment with botulinum toxin type A to the non-paralyzed side, according to the Institution Protocol. To the participants of Group B, botulinum toxin was applied before myofunctional therapy.

intervention.description: All the patients received a one-time treatment with botulinum toxin type A to the non-paralyzed side, according to the Institution Protocol,the total dose used per patient ranged from 15-69U, mean 37.9Â±5.4U.

All the patients were submitted to individual myofunctional therapy with the speech therapist, once a week, by four weeks.The myofunctional therapy began with isometric maneuvers for muscular elongation on the non paralyzed side, and on the paralyzed side when microsurgical reconstruction was present. It also included isotonic maneuvers to increase muscle tonus and isokinetic maneuvers to increase force on the paralyzed side.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- facial paralysis with more than 2 years elapsed since the onset of symptoms
- surgically treated for reanimation at least 12 months before
- static and/or dynamic facial asymmetry causing aesthetic concern
Exclusion Criteria:
- spastic paralysis
- serious systemic or neuromuscular diseases
- cognition impairment
- pregnant women
